acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mr. Gunzburg in several installments between October 1982 and 1989.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collection processed in March 1987, revised in November 1988 and May 1989.

All duplicated materials have been returned to the donor. Copies of the booklet "Your Life Today and Tomorrow: One Man's Message" can be found in the control folder and in the Special Collections and Archives stacks.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Ernest Gunzburg was born 29 December 1911. He was educated in Mainz, Germany and immigrated to the United States in 1935. Soon after arriving in the United States, Gunzburg began working with the National Refugee Service to help settle European refugees in Virginia. In 1939, he relocated, having accepted the position of executive director with the Florida Resettlement Committee. Gunzburg served with the U.S. Army Intelligence during World War II, returning to Virginia to help place persons displaced by the War.

After the war, Gunzburg became an insurance agent for Prudential. An active member of the community, he also played major roles in the establishment of the Richmond Symphony, an Ecumenical Committee in Richmond (Commemoration of Faith), Friends of Newly Naturalized Citizens, Appreciation of America Day, and a crime prevention program for school children. Gunzburg was also involved with a number of other organizations including the Language Bank, the American Red Cross (International Committee), the Richmond Jaycees (Spring Street Chapter), and the Richmond Chamber of Commerce. Gunzburg advocated for the passage of a Bill of Responsibilities for all citizens, and he has spoken to many groups regarding his varied interests.
Gunzburg, who died 22 November 1990, was the recipient of numerous awards and citations presented in recognition his work with civic groups and organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The collection is comprised of correspondence and articles focusing on Mr. Gunzburg's work with immigrants, new citizens, youth, the Richmond Symphony and Chamber of Commerce, Appreciation of America Day, the Language Bank and the program "This is Your Life: Today and Tomorrow".

Correspondents include Senator Harry Byrd, Jr., Representative Tom Bliley, Senator John Warner, Governors Chuck Robb and Mills Godwin, mayors Merrill Crowe and Eleanor Sheppard, Thomas Boushall (Bank of Virginia), George Meaney (AFL-CIO), and other local officials and dignitaries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged alphabetically by subject.
